pullrequest.title: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

content.raw:
The behaviour of this feature is a little unpredictable/modal if one manually changes the shot output folder. Here’s an example:

* Relevant labconfig bits read:

```
[default]
experiment_shot_storage = %(shared_drive)s\Experiments%(experiment_name)s

[runmanager]
output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}
filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}
```

* Start with a default output folder \(pressing the ‘Reset to default output folder’ next to the ‘Shot output folder’ in runmanager\). In my case this is C:\\Experiments\\example\_experiment\\test\\2019\\03\\27\\00001.

    * `.next_sequence_index` gets created in C:\\Experiments\\example\_experiment\\test.
    * After each sequence compilation, the sequence index increments and the shot output folder changes accordingly. So far so good.
    
* Now click on the ‘Select folder…' button next to the shot output folder path \(or just manually change the path\). I chose C:\\Experiments\\example\_experiment\\test:

    * Folders of the form `{sequence_index:05d}` are not created for new sequences. 
    * The filename prefix is still honoured; the sequence index increments after each sequence compilation;
    * There is no longer an indication of what the sequence index is in the runmanager GUI.
    * The ‘Reset to default output folder’ becomes active \(no longer greyed out\).
    
*  Change the shot output folder to C:\\Experiments\\example\_experiment\\test\\2019\\03\\27. Same behaviour as above.
* Manually create a sub-folder of this path with the next sequence index, and select it in runmanager, i.e. C:\\Experiments\\example\_experiment\\test\\2019\\03\\27\\00006.

    * The ‘Reset to default output folder’ becomes greyed out once more.
    * The output folder automatically changes along with the sequence index after each sequence compilation. 
    

I suppose all of this behaviour is by design, and the indicator of the modality is the state of the ‘Reset to default output folder’ button. My only feedback is that this is not very prominent; perhaps a message about the shot output folder not conforming to the format specified by labconfig would be useful. I was concerned that this feature might have compromised the utility of manually choosing the shot output folder \(if there ever was any\), but I’m not after having learnt how it works from the above soak testing.
content.html:
The behaviour of this feature is a little unpredictable/modal if one manually changes the shot output folder. Here’s an example:

  • Relevant labconfig bits read:
[default]
experiment_shot_storage = %(shared_drive)s\Experiments%(experiment_name)s

[runmanager]
output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}
filename_prefix_format = %%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}

  • Start with a default output folder (pressing the ‘Reset to default output folder’ next to the ‘Shot output folder’ in runmanager). In my case this is C:\Experiments\example_experiment\test\2019\03\27\00001.

    • .next_sequence_index gets created in C:\Experiments\example_experiment\test.
    • After each sequence compilation, the sequence index increments and the shot output folder changes accordingly. So far so good.

  • Now click on the ‘Select folder…' button next to the shot output folder path (or just manually change the path). I chose C:\Experiments\example_experiment\test:

    • Folders of the form {sequence_index:05d} are not created for new sequences.
    • The filename prefix is still honoured; the sequence index increments after each sequence compilation;
    • There is no longer an indication of what the sequence index is in the runmanager GUI.
    • The ‘Reset to default output folder’ becomes active (no longer greyed out).

  • Change the shot output folder to C:\Experiments\example_experiment\test\2019\03\27. Same behaviour as above.

  • Manually create a sub-folder of this path with the next sequence index, and select it in runmanager, i.e. C:\Experiments\example_experiment\test\2019\03\27\00006.

    • The ‘Reset to default output folder’ becomes greyed out once more.
    • The output folder automatically changes along with the sequence index after each sequence compilation.

I suppose all of this behaviour is by design, and the indicator of the modality is the state of the ‘Reset to default output folder’ button. My only feedback is that this is not very prominent; perhaps a message about the shot output folder not conforming to the format specified by labconfig would be useful. I was concerned that this feature might have compromised the utility of manually choosing the shot output folder (if there ever was any), but I’m not after having learnt how it works from the above soak testing.

pullrequest.title: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

content.raw:
Thanks for testing!

Yes, it’s all by design, and this is no different to what it was like before this change, except then folders could only be based on the date, now they can be based on the sequence index too.

I’ve added a 'warning' indicator icon with a tooltip to emphasise if you are using a non-default output folder:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/6g5bg5/images/1205243120-runmanager_tooltip.png)
‌
content.html:
Thanks for testing!

Yes, it’s all by design, and this is no different to what it was like before this change, except then folders could only be based on the date, now they can be based on the sequence index too.

I’ve added a 'warning' indicator icon with a tooltip to emphasise if you are using a non-default output folder:

‌

pullrequest.title: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

content.raw: Will merge this on Monday April 8 if there are no comments.

pullrequest.title: Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

content.raw:
For posterity, this pull request permits [integer indexing of the lyse dataframe](#!/labscript_suite/lyse/pull-requests/39), by adding the following to labconfig:

```
[lyse]
integer_indexing = True
```

\(Edited 2019-05-22: Changed boolean value above to `True`.\)
content.html:
For posterity, this pull request permits integer indexing of the lyse dataframe, by adding the following to labconfig:

[lyse]
integer_indexing = True

(Edited 2019-05-22: Changed boolean value above to True.)
